questions.prompt: What is the main benefit of Continuous Integration (CI)?
questions.explanation: CI automatically builds and tests code on every commit, catching integration issues early before they compound.

questions.prompt: Which platform is recommended for deploying Next.js applications?
questions.explanation: Vercel is built specifically for Next.js (by the same team), offering automatic deployments, serverless functions, and excellent developer experience.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of environment variables in deployment?
questions.explanation: Environment variables externalize configuration (API keys, database URLs) so code can run in different environments without changes.

questions.prompt: When a production deployment fails, you should always rollback to the previous working version first before debugging.
questions.explanation: Always rollback first to restore service, then debug the issue in a non-production environment to minimize downtime.

questions.prompt: What is the main purpose of application monitoring tools like Sentry?
options: To detect and track errors in production
questions.explanation: Monitoring tools track errors and exceptions in production, providing stack traces and context to help debug issues.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment?
options: CI automates testing; CD automates deployment to production
questions.explanation: CI automatically builds and tests code on every commit. CD extends this by automatically deploying passing builds to production.

questions.prompt: What is Docker and why is it useful?
options: A containerization platform that packages apps with dependencies
questions.explanation: Docker containers package applications with all dependencies, ensuring consistent behavior across development, testing, and production environments.

options: A text file with instructions to build a Docker image
questions.explanation: A Dockerfile contains instructions (FROM, RUN, COPY, CMD) to build a Docker image, defining the environment and how to run the application.

questions.prompt: What should a CI/CD pipeline include at minimum?
options: Build, test, and deploy stages with failure notifications
questions.explanation: A good CI/CD pipeline includes automated build, test (unit/integration), and deployment stages with notifications when steps fail.

questions.prompt: Deployment previews create temporary environments for each pull request, allowing you to test changes before merging.
questions.explanation: Deployment previews create temporary environments for each pull request, allowing you to test changes in isolation before merging to production.

questions.prompt: What metrics should you monitor in production?
options: Error rates, response times, resource usage, and user activity
questions.explanation: Monitor error rates, API response times, CPU/memory usage, database performance, and user activity to catch issues early.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of application logging?
options: To record events and debug issues in production
questions.explanation: Logging records application events, errors, and debugging information, helping you understand what happened when issues occur in production.

questions.prompt: What is a rollback strategy and why is it important?
options: A way to quickly revert to previous version when deployment fails
questions.explanation: A rollback strategy allows you to quickly revert to the previous working version if a deployment introduces critical bugs, minimizing downtime.

questions.prompt: What is health check endpoint and why is it important?
options: An API to check user health data
An endpoint that verifies the application is running correctly
questions.explanation: Health check endpoints (like /health) verify application and dependencies are working, allowing load balancers and monitoring to detect failures.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between logs and metrics?
options: Logs are event records; metrics are numerical measurements over time
questions.explanation: Logs are detailed event records (timestamped messages). Metrics are numerical measurements over time (CPU usage, request count, response time).
